segments.text: Lucy was not like all the other mothers.
It began with her very unique appearance.
She was tall and carried herself with grace, always dressed in a modest way, but somehow managed to make every outfit, no matter how simple, her own, adding a little twist.
If she wore a white silk shirt tucked into a skirt, she would replace the standard plastic buttons with green glass beads or pearl-like circles.
She had decorative pins she would attach to her shirt or dress.
And by the late fifties, she had already begun wearing pantsuits, which were quite sensational at the time.
The way she slightly lifted the collar of her shirt beneath a jacket gave her a youthful look, adding a touch of bohemian chic to her classic style.
you could immediately notice her upright head, her beautiful face framed by silver hair, with that central white streak that was colored by the tragedy she experienced.
Her hair was gathered in a banana, hairstyle at the back, held with a pin inlaid with pearl-like beads, which she threaded herself.
From that handsome and upright head, undefined eyes appeared, seemingly gray, and she drew her eyebrows, which had also fallen out on that terrible night, with a delicate pencil.
From this appearance reflected a deep expression, radiating power laced with gentleness and human warmth, determination and wisdom dipped in humor.
She spoke seven languages, Hebrew, English, French, Russian, Polish, German and Yiddish, and even a bit of Danish.
For some time, a Danish engineer lived in the pink house who came to establish the Ednir Ice Cream Factory in Kiryat, Milwaukee.
Since he hardly knew English, Lucy acquired a book to learn Danish and spent whole days reciting that terrible language just so she could talk to him and alleviate his loneliness.
She also had a good mind for mathematics, which always benefited the hotel's economy.
But no less so for the poker games she would join when a hand was missing for the men, often beating them.
Sharp mind they would laugh.
and she knew how to drink.
She would stand behind the bar and join those sitting in front of her, drinking a glass of cognac, whiskey, and occasionally wine.
You would never feel that she had drunk.
It was Joseph who would get tipsy and overly cheerful, while she, as if nothing,

She worked very hard for long hours in the hotel kitchen, but there was something almost elegant about how she would send both hands back, untie the apron knot on her body, and remove it, then send the same two hands to her temples, running them through her silver hair as two combs, as if summarizing the workday
knowing that now it was time to take the two steps out of the kitchen and sit at the first table in the dining room, giving rest to her legs and soul, as if going from slavery to freedom.
At any given moment, when she folded her apron and left the kitchen, she looked like she had just emerged from a bubble bath.
and she always smelled wonderful, and there were her whistles.
She had absolute pitch.

She never played any instrument, but she would softly, gently whistle entire compositions with all their nuances, going up and down in tones, sometimes tapping her fingers on the counter to keep the right rhythm.
She would whistle mainly while working in the kitchen or the garden she loved so much.
Throughout the day, music accompanied her.

She had a collection of records from classical music through jazz and French chansons, Yves Montan, about whom she would say how charming he is, to Frank Sinatra and Nat King Cole, about whom she always said, his voice is like velvet and many, many others.
The music always played in the background.
And there was also their pride at whistle, the opening of Beethoven's fifth, which indicated it was time to come home.
Her style was also evident in the home's design.
There were always spotless tablecloths and small flower vases on every table, matching cloth napkins and sparkling drink glasses.
Joseph's paintings were framed according to her instructions and hung each in accordance with the space.
she upholstered the armchair in the corner herself and above the beautiful wooden bar hung her collections from the flea market.
From there she also brought the small old Persian rug laid at the foot of the piano.
She created a magical world of her own and you could feel how much she loved what she found in it a new every morning.
There was just this thing that she hardly ever left the house.
In Aphrodare, everyone walked on the paths paved between the houses.
In ten minutes, you could reach the clock center just like the sea.
Not her.
She couldn't bring herself to walk those few minutes from the house to the clock center.
Something about the wide expanses on the way terrified her.
Joseph became her foreign minister.
I need air, he would say.
Almost every day he would go and sit at Kukitsli Ash, or Madan, in a kind of parliament of friends.
Often, his daughter Lyora would join him, sitting on his lap and listening to the adults gossip.
He would return and update Lucy on all the latest scandals that occurred in Peyton Place.
which Aphrodar was in those days.
And so, since their pink house was also a hotel and a bar and a restaurant, the outside world came to the house, partially solving the problem.
Once a month, Lucy would take a taxi to Tel Aviv, Rudy the neighbor who managed Yale southward.

would make sure she was picked up from home, and she would get off in Tel Aviv, visit her old friends from her days at the Brune Theater and the Impressario Valin, do some shopping, sometimes see a show with Joseph, but stayed within the familiar hundred square meters between Allen B. and Guyula Street, and then return home.
Leora was then young and didn't understand there was a problem with her mother hardly leaving the house.
Only years after she passed away, did she learn it was called agoraphobia, the fear of open places, those she might not be able to escape from in time without being harmed, especially when alone.
This was the addition to the white streak painted that night in her hair.
It caught her in one moment.
While walking, she found herself covered entirely in cold sweat, spreading throughout her body, accompanied by a shiver.
Her legs seemed planted in place, refusing to move.
A feeling of panic and helplessness filled her.
She looked right and left to see if any passers-by noticed her, but they all hurried about their business.
Not paying attention to the young woman standing in the middle of the sidewalk unable to move.
She tried to gather herself to force her mind against the anxiety attack that overtook her.
I must return home.
I cannot just stand here.
What happened to me, she thought.
This was the first time she left the house since the incident occurred.

She had managed to accompany her seven-year-old daughter to the nearby school, but as soon as she parted from her, letting go of her little hand after a few steps, the fear and a cold sweat overwhelmed her.
She walked back slowly, forcing herself to walk just a few steps at a time, to control the shaking in her legs, supporting herself on the fence stretched between the two houses she had to pass.
making pauses to breathe, and eventually crossed the short distance and entered her home.
She collapsed, exhausted on the armchair in the corner of the room.
Feeling the air slowly returning to her lungs, rested her head back, closed her eyes, and suddenly the terrible moments returned to her.
Two weeks earlier, she had married her beloved Avraham in a modest ceremony.
It was a second marriage for both.
She had a daughter from her first marriage and he had two children.
She knew immediately that such love was not found every day.
Movie like love, their friends would say.
He loved her wholeheartedly and carried her on his hands from the moment they met.
And she, every look into his eyes, completely melted her.
Avraham owned Hawaii Garden Cafe on the banks of the Yarkon and operated the rowing dock by the river in partnership with his friends from the brigade.
She tried to help him in the evenings as much as she could, besides her work as a costume designer at the Broome Theater.
That day, he left for the cafe before her.
When she arrived, about an hour later, the place was already bustling with partygoers who came to enjoy and have fun, some dancing to the band's tunes.
She looked around for Avraham and saw him at the far end of the cafe, standing and talking with.
Mayor Taumi.
As if sensing her gaze, he suddenly raised his eyes, met hers and waved to her with a warm, wide smile.
In a moment, he returned to his affairs.
She exchanged a few words with one of the workers.
Around her, there was a cheerful hum of pleasant activity.
She was very glad he was able to fill the place every evening.
With Mayor Tatoumi's help, who assisted artistically, the place had become sought after by patrons.
It was something magical about his place on the banks of the Yarkon.
And the fact that you had to reach it by boat, far from the bustling crowd within the city, naturally attracted many loving couples.
She had helped him furnish the place with beautiful wicker furniture, and together it created a delightful atmosphere of entertainment.
She raised her eyes to him again.
He stood with his back to her next to Ibrahim al-Baitis, his Arab partner from Jaffa.
who owned the land on which the café was built, a quiet and pleasant man.
They spoke between them, and she had already started walking towards them when shouts suddenly rang out.
After them, for a moment, the hum of activity around stopped, and a chilling silence spread for a split second.
She heard Ibrahim call out in Arabic, no, no, and a second later gunfire erupted from all sides.
People screamed hysterically, some fleeing, some lying on the ground.
One of the workers pushed her behind a wall and ordered her to crouch and hide.
He himself took a few steps forward, still crouching, and then she saw him lying down with blood oozing from his leg.
All the while the gunfire did not cease.
She hid behind piled wicker chairs.
Hidden from view, her heart pounded wildly.
Around her were shouts and screams, and she just wanted to know what happened to Avraham.
The entire event lasted minutes that seemed like an eternity.
Suddenly,
as if a switch had been flipped and awful silence fell.
Deadly silence.
Only after an eternity did cries for help, groans and moans.
She slowly emerged from her hiding place, looked at this magical place, now resembling a battlefield and began to run towards where Avraham had stood earlier.
She didn't notice that she was stumbling into people.
She just wanted to get to him.
Suddenly she froze in place seeing her fresh husband, her beloved,
The man who brought healing to her heart, lying on the ground, blood flowing from his chest, lifeless.
She collapsed beside him, hugging his dead body and wailing in terrible tears.
A few meters from him also lay mere ta'umi, and beside the drink's counter lay injured Ibrahim al-Baitis.
From that moment on, she remembered nothing.
Someone forcibly detached her hands from Avraham's body and carried her in his arms to one of the boats to transfer her to safety.
On another boat were placed the bodies of Avraham and Taumi, and another boat transported the wounded to the city.
They all arrived at Hadassah Hospital, which then stood on Balfour Street in the heart of Tel Aviv.
The entire settlement was agitated by the traumatic event that happened one just two months before the state's declaration.
Many people accompanied them on their last journey.
and car traffic ceased during the funeral until their arrival at the cemetery in Nahlat Yitzhak.

She fainted and came to alternately throughout all those hours, refusing to believe all this was really happening, wishing to wake up from this nightmare, but deep in her heart, knowing this was it, that it was over.
On the night the white streak was colored in her hair, marked the fear that caused her to hardly leave her home, certainly not alone.
creating that whole world of her own and turning her home into her fortress.
